data.title: Make package.activate() async.
data.body:
I think that `PackageManager` and `Package` should be resigned to be truly async and make heavy use of ES6 Promises (removing the dependency on `Q`). For example, `package.activate()` should have the option to return a `Promise`, and the package should not be considered "loaded" until that `Promise` is resolved.

Then it would be possible to depend on other packages as follows:

``` coffee
  activate: (state) ->
    # This package is not considered activated until the shared-logging package is activated.
    return atom.packages.activate 'shared-logging'
```

Then `PackageManager` and `Package` would have to be updated to use these `Promise`s all the way through. For example, `Package.activateNow()` would have to become something like:

``` coffee
  activateNow: ->
    try
      @activateConfig()
      @activateStylesheets()
      if @requireMainModule()
        maybePromise = @mainModule.activate(atom.packages.getPackageState(@name) ? {})
        if maybePromise instanceof Promise: # or maybe just check for then() method
          return maybePromise
        else
          return Promise.resolve null
    catch e
      console.warn "Failed to activate package named '#{@name}'", e.stack
```

and callers of `activateNow()` would invoke `then()` on the return value, as appropriate.

data.title: Custom element specificity isn't directly replaceable for class-based styles
Alt+{letter} menu shortcuts and arrow key navigation don't work on Windows and Linux
data.body:
The normal Windows `Alt+{letter}` menu shortcuts don't work in Atom. Holding `Alt` highlights the relevant letter in each menu name, but then pressing the letter doesn't open the menu. For example, `Alt+F` should open the File menu, but instead the Key Binding Resolver shows it invoking the following:

```
editor:move-to-end-of-word    atom-text-editor    resources\app\keymaps\emacs.json
```

This is a vanilla install of Atom 0.141.0 in Windows 7 Home Premium x64. I haven't opted in to enabling anything Emacs related.

Pressing Alt also doesn't focus the menu bar and allow it to be navigated by arrow keys like it normally does in Windows.

I'm reporting this per [this suggestion](https://discuss.atom.io/t/alt-key-menu-bar-interaction-overrides-shortuts/9192/5)

data.title: Lint themes, commands, and keymaps for deprecated selectors
data.body:
Now that we've converted to custom elements, classes like `.workspace` on the `atom-workspace` element are redundant. We should remove them after the deprecation period, so we need to warn users about using them.
- [x] Find `.workspace` suggest `atom-workspace`
- [x] Find  `.bracket-matcher` and suggest `.bracket-matcher .region`
- [x] Find `.editor` in UI themes and suggest `atom-text-editor`, or if it is intended to be a syntax extension, explain the `file.atom-text-editor.less` file.
- [x] `.editor`, `.editor-colors` in syntax themes should target `:host` instead for shadow DOM support. Both can be present for backward compatibility with the disabled feature flag.
- [x] `.editor.mini` should be `.editor[mini]` because `mini` will be an attribute.
- [x] Find `.overlay` and suggest `atom-panel[location="modal"]` in #4045
- [x] Find `.tool-panel` and `.panel-*` suggest `atom-panel[location="*"]` (e.g. `.panel-bottom` suggest `atom-panel[location="bottom"]`) in https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/4063

data.title: Make deprecated SpacePen view exports available as a library
data.body:
This PR removes the following views from core and makes them available in the [atom-space-pen-views](https://github.com/atom/atom-space-pen-views) library on npm.
- TextEditorView
- ScrollView
- SelectListView

These views are now based on a new version of SpacePen that uses custom elements to provide attach/detach hooks instead of relying on patches to jQuery DOM manipulation in atom/atom, which will be going away. They should be able to be used pretty much exactly as the old views were, except that simulated DOM attachment won't trigger attach hooks.

For the time being we need to continue to export a version of these views that behaves exactly the same, including a [bunch of Atom-specific extensions](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/space-pen-extensions.coffee) to SpacePen and jQuery that don't really belong in the extracted libraries. I've solved the problem by injecting Atom's extended version of SpacePen/jQuery into the prototype of these views when they are imported. I also needed to enable the jQuery-style attach hooks (rather than custom-element-based hooks) for the exported views.
### Tasks
- [x] Extract views from core
- [x] Extract CSS from core
- [ ] Get specs passing
- [ ] Document changes to SpacePen
- [ ] Write a readme for atom-space-pen-views npm

data.title: Issue with OS X Yosemite
data.body:
I can't get the latest version of Atom (0.141.0) working very well in Yosemite, and I'm not sure why. I can open files and edit them just fine. As soon as I go to Preferences, an empty web inspector pops up. I can close it, but it will just open up again. 

If I leave this for about a minute, the Preferences screen does show up but I cannot interact with it at all. Then the console starts filling up and roughly every 10 seconds throws `Uncaught RangeError: Maximum call stack size exceeded` for `underscore.js` and `underscore-plus.js`. The editor then crashes upon interaction.

May be worth noting the Atom Helper spikes to 100% CPU load during the whole thing. I did not have these issues on Mavericks, but then again - I had not used Atom for months.

data.title: `cmd-L` should scroll
data.body:
I had originally submitted https://discuss.atom.io/t/scroll-to-bottom-on-selecting-lines-cmd-l/13017 but it was suggested that it is a bug rather than a feature.

If I hit `cmd-L` multiple times to select multiple rows, when I reach the bottom of the visible portion of the window, then `cmd-L` will select lines that aren't visible.  Since I've already seen the first lines when doing I started doing `cmd-L`, may I propose that the view scrolls to keep the bottom line visible?  (I guess it would also be nice to see some of the lines that aren't selected yet.)

`cmd-L` refers to the "Editor: Select Line" command available in the command palette.
